body: The budget of this task is **30 mins**. This is exactly how much time will be compensated, when the task is completed.
@carlosmiranda the task is for you now, follow [these guidelines](http://www.tpc2.com/dev/principles). Don't hesitate to ask any technical questions right here
Re-naming this issue from "MkAssignees.java:43-47: Assignees mock should be implemented...." to "MkAssignees.java:41-45: Assignees mock should be implemented...."
@carlosmiranda ping... Please update me on the status here
Hi @dmarkov . Still waiting on #92 which is waiting on #116. You may assign me another task if you want. Thanks!

I have a question. As per the Assignees API, the list of collaborators are the "owner + collaborators" of the repo. I can get the owner from Repo.coordinates().user(), and I need to combine it with the list of collaborators returned by Collaborators.iterate(). The code I have in mind goes something like this: ``` final User owner = new MkUser(this.storage, Repo.coordinates().user()); final Iterable collaborators = this.repo().collaborators(); //todo: combine the two results above ``` The options that I am considering are: 1. The "vanilla" JDK does not support adding to a plain Iterable. I can create a Set or List instead, add both results into this set and use it as the return value. 2. Use a library such as Guava which has the capability of combining multiple iterators into one. However, our project currently does not include these as dependencies and I'd need to put that library in for the sake of resolving this ticket. My question is, which of the above is the preferred approach? Alternatively, is there a more preferable idiom than those that I've mentioned?

issue.title: Issue #92 Implemented MkAssigneesTest

issue.body: NOTE: Methods are ignored pending resolution of #93, which will fully implement the tested functionality.

body: Good question. Let's use plain vanilla JDK approach. We're developing a library and it's good to keep it free of third-party dependencies, as much as possible.
